DSS_METRIC_DESCRIPTIONS.METRIC_DESCRIPTION: Never use SQL queries with a cartesian product (SQL)

Cartesian joins which lead to cartesian products is an absolute performance killer, especially when large data sets are involved. A cartesian join is a multiple-table query that does not explicitly state a join condition among the tables, it creates a Cartesian product. A Cartesian product consists of every possible combination of rows from the tables. This result set is usually extremely large and unwieldy, killing application performance. In addition, most of the time, this is also a functional bug.

List all SQL Artifacts which contain a query that has a cartesian join, i.e; that does not explicitly state a join condition among the tables A cartesian join is found if, for any of the table in the from clause, no column of the table is found in a join (either in the from or where clause).
Check the statement and if so, add a join clause between the tables.

Select * from table1, table2
Select count(*) from publishers ->3 rows Select count(*) from roysched ->87 rows Select count(*) from Titles -> 18 rows
Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r --> 4698 rows( 87 x 18 x 3)
Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r Where p.pub_id = t.pub_id --> 1566 rows ( 87 x 18)
Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r Where p.pub_id = t.pub_id AND r.royalty = 14 --> 252 rows

Select * from table1 T1 inner join table2 T2 on (T1.C = T2.C)
example of non cartesian product: Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r Where p.pub_id = t.pub_id AND t.title_id = r.title_id --> 87 rows
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Never use SQL queries with a cartesian product on XXL Tables (SQL)

Cartesian joins which lead to cartesian products are an absolute performance killer, especially when large data sets are involved which is the case when extremely large tables are involved. A cartesian join is a multiple-table query that does not explicitly state a join condition among the tables, it creates a Cartesian product. A Cartesian product consists of every possible combination of rows from the tables. This result set is usually extremely large and unwieldy, killing application performance. In addition, most of the time, this is also a functional bug.

List all SQL Artifacts (except tables) which contain a query on XXL tables that have a cartesian join, i.e; that does not explicitly state a join condition among the tables A cartesian join is found if, for any of the tables in the from clause, no column of the table is found in a join (either in the from or where clause). XXL tables are extremely large tables which contain a huge amount of data. The threshold that determines when a table is considered to contain a huge amount of data can be configured by the user.
Check the statement and if so, add a join clause between the tables.

Select * from table1, table2
Select count(*) from publishers ->3 rows Select count(*) from roysched ->87 rows Select count(*) from Titles -> 18 rows
Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r --> 4698 rows( 87 x 18 x 3)
Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r Where p.pub_id = t.pub_id --> 1566 rows ( 87 x 18)
Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r Where p.pub_id = t.pub_id AND r.royalty = 14 --> 252 rows

Select * from table1 T1 inner join table2 T2 on (T1.C = T2.C)
example of non cartesian product: Select p.pub_name, p.city, t.title, r.royalty From publishers p, titles t, roysched r Where p.pub_id = t.pub_id AND t.title_id = r.title_id --> 87 rows
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code from schemas containing XXL tables or views.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid non-indexed SQL queries
Non-indexed SQL Queries are potentially performance killers. Indeed, each execution of the query will result in a full table scan which is extremely time consuming.

This metric retrieves the artifacts with at least one table accessed on non-indexed columns. A SQL query is considered indexed when all the following conditions are true:
- At least one index is accessed for each non XXS table - the access is on the left-most columns of the indexes
An XXS table is a table containing an extremely low amount of data. Default is 10. The threshold that determines when a table XXS can be configured by the user in the same manner as for XXL tables.
Check the statement and if so, add secondary index on queried columns.
Enhancing the Quality of ABAP Development Meijs - Krouwels - Heuvelmans - Sommen SAP Press ISBN 1-59229-030-2

TABLE1 is indexed on (COL2, COL1) and TABLE2 on COL3. Both tables are not XXS. For the following statement : Select O.COL1, O.COL2, O.COL2, 1, 0, 0, 1 From TABLE1 O, TABLE2 OT Where O.COL3 = OT.COL3 And O.COL1 in (1, 2) And OT.COL4 = 1; TABLE2's index cover the statement. TABLE1 is reported in violation.
The remediation is to add index on TABLE1 (COL3, COL1).

Associated to each Artifact with violations, the Quality Rule provides: - The number of violation patterns. - Each violation pattern shows : - the query - each table accessed on non-indexed columns - the table's indexes
Number of Artifacts with SQL code from schemas containing tables or views.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid non-indexed XXL SQL queries

Non-indexed SQL Queries are potentially performance killers. Indeed, each execution of the query will result in a full table scan which is extremely time consuming especially if the table contains an extremely large amount of data (XXL table).

This metric retrieves the artifacts with at least one XXL table accessed on non-indexed columns. A SQL query is considered on indexed columns when all the following conditions are true:
- At least one index is accessed for each XXL table - The access is on the left-most columns of the indexes
XXL tables are extremely large tables which contain a huge amount of data. The threshold that determines when a table is considered to contain a huge amount of data can be configured by the user.
Check the statement and if so, add seconday index on queried columns.
Enhancing the Quality of ABAP Development Meijs - Krouwels - Heuvelmans - Sommen SAP Press ISBN 1-59229-030-2

TABLE1 is indexed on (COL2, COL1) and TABLE2 on COL3. Both tables are XXL. For the following statement : Select O.COL1, O.COL2, O.COL2, 1, 0, 0, 1 From TABLE1 O, TABLE2 OT Where O.COL3 = OT.COL3 And O.COL1 in (1, 2) And OT.COL4 = 1; TABLE2's index cover the statement. TABLE1 is reported in violation.
The remediation is to add index on TABLE1 (COL3, COL1).

Associated to each Artifact with violations, the Quality Rule provides: - The number of violation patterns. - Each violation pattern shows : - the query - each XXL table accessed on non-indexed columns - the XXL table's indexes
Number of Artifacts with SQL code from schemas containing XXL tables or views.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid non-SARGable queries
non-SARGable WHERE clauses are performances killers : for a non-SARGable query, the query optimizer has to scan all the rows in the table even if that column has an index.
List all SQL Artifacts containing a query that has only non-SARGable arquments expressions in where clauses or in the join.
Check the statement and if so, replace non-SARGable predicates with SARGable.

-- Index scan (slow) WHERE UPPER(ColumnValue) = 'SUMMER' -- not sargable predicate
------------ -- Table scan or index scan on a primary key index -- no index use on ColumnValue WHERE SUBSTRING(ColumnValue,1,3) = 'sum' -- not sargable predicate
------------ -- Table scan - no index use on ColumDate WHERE year(ColumDate) = 2017 and month(ColumDate) = 1 -- not sargable predicate
------------ -- not sargable predicate due to function use -- Table scan WHERE floor(ColumnValue) = 50 -- not sargable predicate

-- Index seek (fast) WHERE ColumnValue = 'Summer' -- sargable predicate
------------ -- Index seek if there is an index on ColumnValue WHERE ColumnValue LIKE 'sum%' -- sargable predicate
------------ -- Index seek WHERE ColumDate >='2017-01-01' and ColumDate < '2017-02-01' -- sargable predicate
------------ -- Index seek if there is an index on ColumnValue WHERE ColumnValue = 50 -- sargable predicate
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid NATURAL JOIN queries

A NATURAL JOIN is a type of equi-join which implicitly compares all identically-named columns of the two tables. While this a feature may seem convenient at first, it becomes hard to maintain over time.
List all SQL Artifacts containing a query that has NATURAL JOINs.
Check the statement and if so, replace NATURAL JOINs with INNER JOINs.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Specify column names instead of column numbers in ORDER BY clauses
Improve readability by sorting on column names rather than column numbers. Improve maintainability by making the ORDER BY part independent.
List all SQL Artifacts containing a query that has column numbers in ORDER BY clauses.
Check the statement and if so, replace column numbers with column names.
SELECT first_name, department_name FROM employees JOIN departments ON (employees.manager_id = departments.manager_id AND employees.department_id = departments.department_id) ORDER BY 1, 2;

SELECT first_name, department_name FROM employees JOIN departments ON (employees.manager_id = departments.manager_id AND employees.department_id = departments.department_id) ORDER BY first_name, department_name;
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid queries using old style join convention instead of ANSI-Standard joins (SQL)

ANSI syntax allows a clear separation between joins clauses and the where clause restrictions. The ANSI notation makes the relations between the tables explicit, and saves you from coding equality tests for join conditions in the WHERE clause. Support for full outer joins also eliminates the need for complex workarounds to do those queries (with the old syntax some constructions can lead to unexpected behavior). Moreover ANSI joins allows the use of optimization hints.
The old syntax used for joining tables should definitely be abandoned in favor of the standard ANSI syntax, which is more readable and more maintainable.
Check the statement and if so, replace non ANSI-Standard joins with ANSI-Standard joins.
SELECT first_name, department_name FROM employees, departments where(employees.manager_id = departments.manager_id AND employees.department_id = departments.department_id);
SELECT first_name, department_name FROM employees JOIN departments ON (employees.manager_id = departments.manager_id AND employees.department_id = departments.department_id);
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid Artifacts with too many parameters (SQL)
For maintainability and readability reasons, artifacts should not have too many parameters.
Avoid artifacts with more than X parameters. The threshold X is a parameter and it can be changed at will.
Review the design of the artifacts to reduce the number of parameters.
This report lists all artifacts with more than X parameters. It provides the following information: Artifact full name, number of parameters
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of parameters
Avoid using the GROUP BY clause
Using complex queries in Artifacts can cause performance problems. Queries using group by clauses are considered complex and inefficient.
Using complex queries can cause performance problems. Queries using group by clauses are considered complex and inefficient.
Check the statement and if so, review the design of the statement to avoid if possible the GROUP BY clause.

The following query should be reviewed: Select T.title_id, T.def_id, T.publisher_id, T.pub_name into var1_title_id, var1_def_id, var1_publisher_id, var1_pub_name from (Select ALLESQL007_TBL3.title_id, def_id, publisher_id, pub_name from ALLESQL007_TBL1, ALLESQL007_TBL2, ALLESQL007_TBL3 where pub_id = publisher_id and pub_name = authorname Group By ALLESQL007_TBL3.title_id, publisher_id) T Group By T.title_id, T.publisher_id;
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid using quoted identifiers
Quoted identifiers are confusing, as they look similar to string literals.
Quoted identifiers are confusing, as they look similar to string literals.
Check the statement and if so, replace quoted identifiers with unquoted identifiers.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid Tables without Primary Key (SQL)

In relational database design, a candidate key is just a unique identifier. Next, a primary key is a candidate key that's been singled out to uniquely identify each row in a table. A unique key or primary key comprises a single column or set of columns. No two distinct rows in a table can have the same value (or combination of values) in those columns.
Depending on its design, a table may have arbitrarily have many unique keys but at most one primary key.
This metric displays the list of tables without Primary key constraints
Check the statement and if so, add primary key.

The following statement should be reviewed: create table SQLAMDA001_7_TBL1 (category_name varchar2(10) not null , title varchar2(50) null , title_id varchar2(10) null , author_name varchar2(30) null ) /
Add a primary key: alter table SQLAMDA001_7_TBL1 add constraint SQLAMDA001_7_TBL1_PK primary key (category_name) using index /
This report lists all tables without a primary key defined. It provides the full name of each table without a primary key.
Number of Tables.
List of tables without Primary key constraints
Avoid using dynamic SQL in SQL Artifacts

Each repetition of the same dynamic SQL statement incurs a soft parse, which is a small overhead compared to a static statement, but still an overhead. The overhead of dynamic SQL is small, it can be in the thousandths of a second - however, it can add up if this is inside a loop / on a method called once per object.
Dynamic SQL could lead to some performance problems. The execution plan cannot be stored in memory and thus needs to be calculated each time.
Check the statement and if so, replace dynamic with static statement.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Always define column names when inserting values
To preserve code functionality and avoid mistakes with regard to column handling, always explicitly use the column name.
To preserve code functionality and avoid mistakes with regard to column handling, always explicitly use the column name.
Check the statement and if so, add columns in INSERT clause.
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Use MINUS or EXCEPT operator instead of NOT EXISTS and NOT IN subqueries
Using the MINUS or EXCEPT operator instead of NOT IN and NOT Exists will result in a faster execution plan.
Using the MINUS or EXCEPT operator instead of NOT IN and NOT Exists will result in a faster execution plan.
Check the statement and if so, replace NOT EXISTS and NOT IN suqueries with MINUS or EXCEPT operator.

The following procedure should be reviewed: CREATE PROCEDURE INSERT_BOOK_TITLE BEGIN INSERT INTO BOOK_TITLE_COPY SELECT BOOK_TITLE FROM BOOKS WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT BOOK_TITLE FROM SALES WHERE SALES.BOOK_TITLE = BOOKS.BOOK_TITLE); END;
Replace NOT EXISTS suquerie with MINUS operator: CREATE PROCEDURE INSERT_BOOK_TITLE BEGIN INSERT INTO BOOK_TITLE_COPY SELECT BOOK_TITLE FROM BOOKS MINUS SELECT BOOK_TITLE FROM SALES; END;
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid Artifacts with queries on too many Tables and/or Views
Having complex queries in Artifacts can cause performance problems.
Avoid SQL Artifacts with queries on more than X Tables and/or Views. Queries with more than X Tables and/or Views are considered complex.
Review the query to reduce the number of involved Tables and/or Views.

The following procedures should be reviewed: 1. 5 Views are are joined: DELIMITER // CREATE OR REPLACE PROCEDURE SQLCPLEX001_13_DN_SHOW_8_Y() CONTAINS SQL BEGIN DECLARE SQLCPLEX001_var INTEGER; SELECT STDTBL_COL_1_1 INTO SQLCPLEX001_var FROM SQLCPLEX001_8_DN_SHOW_3_Y, SQLCPLEX001_9_DN_SHOW_4_Y, SQLCPLEX001_10_DN_SHOW_5_Y, SQLCPLEX001_11_DN_SHOW_6_Y, SQLCPLEX001_12_DN_SHOW_7_Y; END // DELIMITER ; 2. 5 Tables are joined, STD_TABLE_4 is joined 2 times : DELIMITER // CREATE OR REPLACE PROCEDURE SQLCPLEX001_16_DN_SHOW_12_X() CONTAINS SQL BEGIN DECLARE SQLCPLEX001_var VARCHAR(11); SELECT DISTINCT STD_TABLE_1.COL1, STD_TABLE_2.COL1 FROM STD_TABLE_1, STD_TABLE_2 WHERE STD_TABLE_2.COL1 IN (SELECT COL1 FROM STD_TABLE_3 WHERE COL2 = DATE '1999-04-27') AND STD_TABLE_1.COL1 IN (SELECT COL1 FROM STD_TABLE_4 WHERE STDTBL_COL1_1 = DATE '1999-04-27') AND STD_TABLE_2.COL1 IN (SELECT COL1 FROM STD_TABLE_4 WHERE STDTBL_COL1_1 = DATE '1999-04-28') ; END // DELIMITER ; 3. 5 Tables are joined : DELIMITER // CREATE OR REPLACE PROCEDURE SQLCPLEX001_15_SHOW_11_X() CONTAINS SQL BEGIN DECLARE SQLCPLEX001_var VARCHAR(11); SELECT STD_TABLE_4.STDTBL_COL1_1, STD_TABLE_1.COL1 FROM STD_TABLE_1 INNER JOIN STD_TABLE_2 ON STD_TABLE_2.COL1 = STD_TABLE_1.COL1 INNER JOIN STD_TABLE_3 ON STD_TABLE_3.COL1 = STD_TABLE_2.COL1 INNER JOIN STD_TABLE_4 ON STD_TABLE_4.COL1 = STD_TABLE_3.COL1 INNER JOIN STD_TABLE_5 ON STD_TABLE_5.COL1 = STD_TABLE_4.COL1; END // DELIMITER ;
This report lists all Artifacts, except Views, with queries on too many Tables and/or Views. It provides the following information: Artifact full name
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of joined Tables and/or Views
Avoid exists and not exists independent clauses (SQL)
Identify "exists" and "not exists" independent clauses: - solve a potential performance and disk space issue - applicable for all sql, including embedded sql
List all Artifacts which contain a query having independent "exists" and "not exists" clauses, which are not referring to the parent object
Check the statement and if so, add a join clause between exists and parent object.
The following query should be reviewed: select name from person where exists (select 1 from children)
Add a join between children table from exists clause and person table from parent query: select name from person where exists (select 1 from children where children.fatherid = person.id)
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
DISTINCT should not be used in SQL SELECT statements

Identify "DISTINCT", "DISTINCTROW", "UNIQUE" modifiers in SQL "SELECT" statements: - is frequently a "code smell" - it indicates that something is not quite right because using the DISTINCT keyword means that redundant data is being pulled from the database and then discarded - applicable for all sql, including embedded sql
List all Artifacts having "DISTINCT", "DISTINCTROW", "UNIQUE" modifiers in SQL "SELECT" statements
Check the statement and if so, rearrange the "WHERE" or the "FROM" clause in the SQL "SELECT" statement to only get the rows you need.

The following SQL "SELECT" statement should be reviewed: SELECT DISTINCT u.user_id, u.user_name, u.realname, u.email, u.confirm_hash FROM users u, user_group ug, groups g WHERE u.status='A' AND u.user_id=ug.user_id AND ug.admin_flags='A' AND g.status='A' AND g.group_id=ug.group_id ORDER BY u.user_id;

Add an uncorrelated subquery: SELECT u.user_id, u.user_name, u.realname, u.email, u.confirm_hash FROM users u WHERE u.status = 'A' AND u.user_id IN ( SELECT ug.user_id FROM user_group ug, groups g WHERE ug.admin_flags='A' AND g.status = 'A' AND g.group_id = ug.group_id ) ORDER BY u.user_id;
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Use ANSI standard operators in SQL WHERE clauses
Identify !=, !> and !< operators in SQL WHERE clauses: - to prevent portability issues - applicable only for embedded sql
List all Artifacts having !=, !> and !< operators in SQL WHERE clauses
Check the statement and if so, !=, !> and !< operators with <>, <= or >=<
The following SQL WHERE clause should be reviewed: Select col1, col2, col3 From table1 Where col1 != 1 and col2 !< 2 and col3 !> 3 Order By col1, col2;
Replace non-ANSI operators: Select col1, col2, col3 From table1 Where col1 <> 1 and col2 <= 2 and col3 >= 3 Order By col1, col2
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Replace OR conditions testing equality on the same identifier in SQL WHERE clauses by an IN test condition

Identify OR conditions testing equality on the same identifier in SQL WHERE clauses: - one way to improve readability and understandability is to replace them by an IN test condition - applicable for all sql, including embedded sql
List all Artifacts having OR conditions testing equality on the same identifier in SQL WHERE clauses.
Check the statement and if so, replace them by an IN test condition.
The following SQL WHERE clause should be reviewed: SELECT supplier_name, city, state FROM suppliers WHERE supplier_name = 'Microsoft' OR supplier_name = 'Oracle' OR supplier_name = 'Flowers Foods';
Use an IN test condition: SELECT supplier_name, city, state FROM suppliers WHERE supplier_name IN ('Microsoft', 'Oracle', 'Flowers Foods');
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided: - The number of violation occurrences - Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
Number of Artifacts with SQL code.
Number of violation occurrences
Avoid empty catch blocks (SQL)

An empty catch block defeats the purpose of exceptions. When an exception occurs, nothing happens and the program fails for an unknown reason. The application can be in an unknown state that will affect subsequent processing. Since the reason for the issue (the exception type and potential embedded message) are ignored, it will require more time to fix the issue.
In a TRY..CATCH statement, CATCH blocks should have code to handle the thrown exception. If they are empty or only contain comments, the Exception will not be handled.
The exception must be handled correctly according to its type.

An insider's guide to writing robust, understandable, maintainable, state-of-the-art ABAP programs - Part 3 Andreas Blumenthal - Horst Keller

Table naming convention - character set control (SQL)

For readability and changeability aspects, naming conventions must be respected.
=> Table name should not contain characters other than [a-Z,0-9,_]
List of tables that contain characters other than [a-Z,0-9,_]
Change name according to the naming convention

This report lists all tables names containing characters other than [a-Z,0-9,_]
It provides the following information:
- Table name, - Table full name

Package naming convention - prefix control (SQL)
For readability aspects, naming conventions must be respected
Names of Packages should start with X. The prefix value is a parameter that can be changed at will
